FILE: cm020390v11.0.txt
DYAD: DENMARK-CANADA

PSNOTES: 

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20170727
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20170727

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID4549 

TERRMID: MID4549 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4549 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4549 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4549 the disputation of Hans Island is not connected to a maritime dispute, and the maritime boundary on which the island lies is settled. The small island is uninhabitable; from (Stevenson 2007), "both countries assert that the issue is simply one of national sovereignty." Stevenson mentions that there some speculation that the issue is connected to possible natural resources in the area or anticipation of global warming leading to new potential shipping lanes, but this is limited to speculation by outside observers and is not the official position of either country. Of note: “the dispute has no implications for the location of the maritime boundary between Canada and Greenland, or for Canadian or Danish rights elsewhere” (Byers 2013, 14). Note that Byers (2013) five Danish flag plants and Canadian protests, in 1988, 1995, 2002, 2003, and 2004 (Byers 2013, 13).

ISLMID: MID4549 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4549 from cm narrative, occurred 3/2004. Hans Island is disputed between Canada and Denmark. In this MID, Denmark planted a flag on Hans Island, prompting protest from Canada. Coded islands MID because of the disputed sovereignty of the island. 

CIVWARMID: MID4549 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID4549 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID4549 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4549 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4549 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4551 

TERRMID: MID4551 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4551 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4551 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4451 the disputation of Hans Island os not connected to a maritime dispute, and the maritime boundary on which the island lies is settled. The small island is uninhabitable; from (Stevenson 2007), "both countries assert that the issue is simply one of national sovereignty." Stevenson mentions that there some speculation that the issue is connected to possible natural resources in the area or anticipation of global warming leading to new potential shipping lanes, but this is limited to speculation by outside observers and is not the official position of either country. Of note: “the dispute has no implications for the location of the maritime boundary between Canada and Greenland, or for Canadian or Danish rights elsewhere” (Byers 2013, 14).

ISLMID: MID4551 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4451 from cm narrative, occurred 7/23/2005-2/22/2006. The Canadian Defense Minister, along with military personnel, sailed to Hans Island and planted a Canadian flag, usurping the place of the Danish flag (see MID4549). At the same time, the Canadian military increased the number of warships patrolling the region. Coded islands MID because the sovereignty over Hans Island is disputed. 

CIVWARMID: MID4551 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID4551 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID4551 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4551 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4551 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4 2002-2010:

MID4549
rivalry=20390 nationa=DENMARK nationb=CANADA MID4549 20040300-20040300 
 revtype1a=TERRITORY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=TERRITORY revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

Hans Island, located in a shipping lane in the Arctic Ocean, has been disputed between Denmark and Canada. On March 30, 2004, a Danish warship sailed to the island and planted a Danish flag. First and last day of dispute is listed as 3/00/2004.

MID4551
rivalry=20390 nationa=CANADA nationb=DENMARK MID4551 20050723-20060222 
 revtype1a=TERRITORY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=TERRITORY revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

The Canadian Defense Minister, along with military personnel, sailed to Hans Island and planted a Canadian flag, usurping the place of the Danish flag (see MID4549). At the same time, the Canadian military increased the number of warships patrolling the region. First day of dispute was on 7/23/2005 and last day of dispute was on 2/22/2006.

SOURCES-CR: Christopher Stevenson, Hans Off!: The Struggle for Hans Island and the Potential Ramifications for International Border Disupute Resolution , 30 B.C. Int'l & Comp. L. Rev. 263 (2007), http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/iclr/vol30/iss1/16

Byers, Michael. 2013. International Law and the Arctic. Cambridge: Cambridge UP.
